input.content: What is the difference between a migraine and a regular headache?

Migraine is a type of headache, but it is specifically defined as a throbbing, pulsing, or painful headache that is usually located in one side of the head, and can spread to involve the entire head, or any part of the face, or a particular region of the neck.
I'm also feeling very nauseous and sensitive to light.  Are those symptoms of a migraine?

preferred_completion: Nausea and sensitivity to light are also symptoms of migraines.  However, it's more common for these symptoms to last for less than a day in migraine sufferers.  Also, they are often only associated with the actual migraine and not the pre-migraine or post-migraine symptoms.  Migraines can affect the whole body including nausea, vomiting, pain in any area, and sensitivity to light.
other_completion: Sensitivity to light (photophobia) and nausea (nausea, or “upset stomach”) are more common symptoms of the flu or some other type of viral infection, but they are not generally associated with migraines.

input.content: Are time outs helpful for kids?

I would say so.  Most people can learn by having a consequence for when they make a mistake, and time outs is an easy and effective consequence.  But they’re often used too harshly, and so can be ineffective or even counter-productive.
What do you mean too harshly?

To be clear, time outs are an effective consequence for misbehavior, but the child may see them as “time-out jail”, which is something to be avoided, rather than a necessary consequence.  So for me to be effective in helping you set up a good consequence for misbehavior, I would need to learn more about your family and what you’re trying to accomplish.
ok so they might be ok once in a while?

preferred_completion:
Yes, I think they can be helpful when the child misbehaves, but they should be used with a little bit of compassion and understanding that it’s not the natural state of things to have an adult yelling at them.  Time outs are also often used without letting the child know how they’re getting out of the time out, which can make it feel arbitrary or like a punishment, rather than a consequence for something they did.  It’s really easy for adults to do this kind of thing unconsciously.  It’s easy to get caught up in the notion that “They’re in time out, and that’s the end of it!” but kids can be pretty imaginative, and they can use their own creativity to make their way out of time outs.  A compassionate time out ends when the child shows a sign of understanding what they’ve done wrong, and are ready to begin again.  That way the child knows they’re learning, and that the parent is seeing them as an intelligent person, even if they sometimes mess up.  You can still use the other techniques you were using to be tough when necessary, but using a compassionate approach will let you use them without actually using them!


Human
other_completion: If your child has been misbehaving a lot, and it’s because they don’t understand or care about the rules, then a time out could be a good consequence to try.

input.content: Why are so many stores closed on Sundays? Is it a religious reason?

preferred_completion: No.  The USA was founded by a Puritan group of Protestants, but it didn’t adopt the religion of the Puritans until much later, and it was always a secular state.  The Puritans observed the Sabbath on Sunday, and the Puritans only had a small influence in the early history of the USA.  It’s difficult to trace the origins of closing stores on Sunday, but one early and short-lived attempt at forcing the Sabbath on people in the 1800s was motivated by the Protestant ideal that people should spend Sunday focusing on spiritual activities.  By the mid-1800s, when the Sunday closing law was made, there was not a lot of pressure from that standpoint, but the church had begun to advocate for Sunday closing laws as a way of counteracting the negative effects of industrialization on the day of rest.  Even after that shift, closing stores on Sunday was not always possible, since the religious Sunday was not always chosen for observance.  And as industrialization accelerated and mechanization made it possible to operate stores on Sunday, the law was not enforced as much as people liked.  The day of rest was also being violated by stores that stayed open all day on Sunday, so closing stores on Sundays became an effort to protect the Sabbath for all citizens.
other_completion: It’s not religious. There are two reasons for this: stores don’t earn enough revenue on Sundays to pay their staff, and the risk of theft is so high, so they keep the stores closed.

input.content: Can you give me some examples of a palatalization?

The term palatalization refers to a sound shift, and is typically used in a technical sense. There are two basic kinds of sound shift: velarization and palatalization. Velarization refers to a shift from a sound in the back of the mouth to a sound in the front. Palatalization refers to a shift from a sound in the front of the mouth to a sound in the back of the mouth. These types of shifts are actually quite common, as a lot of languages change their sound systems over time. Take the English words for “old” and “cold”. In Old English (also called Anglo-Saxon, or sometimes “OE”), these were pronounced as [a:dl] and [k:ld]. In Middle English (or “ME”), they were pronounced with a “d” that’s like a “t” (like in the “t” in the word “toy”), and [k]. But in Modern English, we now pronounce the “d” more like “t”, and the [k] has palatalized to a [t]. Try pronouncing those two words now with the English pronunciations of each of those Old and Middle English words, and you should get a clear feel for
Would tube be an example?

Oh, not quite. I think the tube example is a little different - it refers to an assimilation, where [u] tends to move closer to [a] (like in the vowel sound of “father”) as a result of being pronounced together with a consonant.  Also, this shift happens from the Middle to the Modern English, not Old to Middle or Modern. Here’s an example:

[Old] TIME [Middle] tima [Modern] tim

There are also other kinds of shifts you might hear, like in English there are words like “thought” and “kneaded” that were spelled the same way in Old English, but pronounced differently. These changes were related to the Great Vowel Shift, where /o:/ sounds moved from a more front position to a more back position. This resulted in things like /ā/ becoming [æ], and /e/ becoming [e].
I thought tube would be a good example of a palatalization as the t makes a 'ch' sound

Oh yes, that’s one example of velarization. Velarization is often used in scientific writing to refer to a front-back movement in the mouth like you’re talking about, but it usually just means in general any kind of sound shift like you’re thinking of.  Can I ask why you’re confused about this?
I have to give examples for a school paper. Do you have any example words I could use that have palatalization when pronounced?

preferred_completion: Sure, you could use the words English words like “pat”, “nap”, and “flap”. In fact, these all sound very similar in pronunciation, and their spelling has changed just a little bit over time to indicate these sound changes. Palatalization refers to any kind of sound shift in the mouth where you end up with a consonant that’s farther back in your mouth. And you can hear that in all these words - the “p”, “t”, and “k” sounds are in the back of your mouth. You’ll also hear the same kind of shift in words like “pick”, “kick”, and “black” when spoken. Can you imagine saying those three words? Which are pronounced with your front teeth and which are pronounced with your back teeth?
other_completion: I’m not sure I have any examples of a palatalization that’s not velarization, though of course many examples of velarization are also palatalizations. But you can try [y] sounds, for example, like the “y” in “yellow”. For example, when I say “yum” (like in “delicious food!”), I’m pronouncing that word in a way that puts it closer to the “ju” in “judicious”. That’s a velarization - we’re palatalizing the /u/ in “yum” towards a /y/ sound. Velarization often happens in sound shifts, like the Great Vowel Shift, but it can also happen on its own, like when I say “yum” to be yummy.

input.content: What is macular degeneration?

Well, macular degeneration is a common condition where the cells in the center of the retina (called the macula) lose their ability to receive light.  This loss of visual function, usually due to damage to the blood vessels that supply the retina, leads to blindness in the affected eye(s).  The condition is very common in people over the age of 60.  It’s not treatable and cannot be reversed.
Do you know what damages the blood vessels that supply the retina?

Yes, it’s caused by the build up of toxic deposits (called drusen) in the eye, similar to the build up of calcium deposits in your arteries that can lead to hardening of the arteries.  The leading causes of this build up of deposits are smoking, high cholesterol levels, high blood pressure, and diabetes.
Can an ophthalmologist see the drusen?
Yes, it’s possible for an ophthalmologist to see them with an ophthalmoscope, or a slit lamp.  They also can use a test called fluorescein angiography to look at the blood flow through the retina.
And can the drusen be removed?

Not at the current time.  Even the fluorescein angiography can’t reliably show where the drusen are located.  The way this disease usually progresses is that first the blood flow slows down in the center of the retina.  In the early stages of the disease, a very low dose of a drug called a vasodilator (like Diamox) can improve the blood flow, but later this can’t be done.  The macular degeneration progresses and eventually the retina becomes disconnected from the central area of the brain that controls vision.
Is testing being done to find a cure for macular degeneration?

preferred_completion: Yes, there’s a very large effort to find better methods of treating macular degeneration and to develop a cure, such as via gene therapy.  There’s also research to find the causes and improve treatments for the conditions that lead to the build up of drusen.  One major focus of this research is to understand how to prevent damage to the blood vessels that supply the retina in the first place.  This involves studying factors like oxidative stress, inflammation, and vascular damage.
other_completion: Yes, a trial is underway at the University of Utah to use gene therapy to prevent the build up of drusen deposits.

preferred_completion: Yeah!  Basically, we use a process called “ceramics” to make crayons.  You can actually see a diagram of it in the linked article.  Basically, we start out with clay, and then heat it up in a kiln, until it melts and becomes a plastic. That plastic is called “ceramic” and we use it for things like crayons and other plastic objects.  The wax is called “paraffin wax” or “wool wax” and it’s used as a glue or a coating for other objects that are made of plastic or other materials, but you can actually buy wax to use for creating your own crayons.

input.content: If you were to float above the ground would the Earth rotate below you?

preferred_completion:
That is a common question I’m asked, and I think it has a tricky answer!  I think my answer is “yes” and “no.”  You may be thinking of “Time Dilation” or “Warp Drive”, but it’s not what I’m thinking of.   What I’m thinking of is the way that our imagination works.

Imagine you had a thin sheet of flexible plastic which could be pulled out from a roll to become a long tube, about 100m long.  We call this a “wormhole”, as in, it’s a flexible wormhole.  If you were floating in space, and grabbed one end of it and held it, then the other end would stretch to the ground, into the ground and back out again.  If you stood on the ground, you could then pull it and have it lift you up into the air.  The question is, could the Earth rotate under the “wormhole” while the person holding it was “in the air”?

The answer is, no.  The “wormhole” analogy is a bit strange, so let me explain it more carefully.

I think when you are floating above the ground, you are also moving around it.  But in the same way that you can hold one end of the wormhole while floating, the Earth is also moving around you.  So you might wonder how it could “rotate” while you are also moving around it.

This is a situation of accelerating motion.  A spaceship, say, accelerates around the Earth so that it is moving at a speed which is near the speed of light.  As it flies past, we say it moves “faster than light” and we call this “tachyonic motion” or “tachyons” for short.  Tachyons are things that accelerate faster than light, and as they pass by, objects may seem to move or “rotate” as they pass, even though the objects themselves are not moving.

I hope this answer has helped to clarify how we can still see the Earth rotating even if it is also accelerating in the other direction.  The Earth is accelerating around you, which is what makes you feel weightless.  This is why it’s called “Weightlessness”.
other_completion: You mean, would the Earth rotate around me, since I’m human and I’m not rotating around the Earth?

input.content: Which foods are high in B Vitamins?

B5 (pantothenic acid) is found in peanuts, mushrooms, potatoes, bananas, chicken, broccoli and whole grains. B6 (pyridoxine) is found in whole grains, liver, potatoes, chicken, bananas, oats, beans and fortified cereals. B7 (biotin) is found in liver, kidneys, fish, whole grains, peanuts, mushrooms, soybeans and cauliflower. B9 (folic acid) is found in green vegetables, liver, wheat germ, whole grains, leafy vegetables and yeast. The B-complex vitamins include thiamin (or vitamin B1), riboflavin (or vitamin B2), niacin (or vitamin B3), pantothenic acid (or vitamin B5), pyridoxine (or vitamin B6), folic acid, biotin, and vitamin B12.  The B vitamins help to support the nervous system and muscles, and enable the body to absorb and process the protein you eat, and convert carbohydrates into glucose for energy.  Some B vitamins help to make the red blood cells in the body work properly, which is also needed for circulation and energy levels.

New England Clam Chowder

Ingredients:

2 cups water

2 bay leaves

4 large carrots, diced

1 large onion, diced

1 stalk celery, diced

1 stalk parsley, chopped

1 teaspoon dried oregano

1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper

1 pound smoked or canned clams, drained

3 tablespoons butter

2 cups flour

1 teaspoon salt

1/4 teaspoon ground black pepper

4 cups milk

Method:

In a large pot, combine water, bay leaves, carrots, onion, celery, parsley, oregano, and black pepper. Simmer for 10 minutes. Remove and discard bay leaves.

Add clams, butter, and flour, and stir until flour is dissolved.  Cook, stirring frequently, until mixture is thickened and bubbly.

Stir in milk, salt, and pepper.

input.content: Do you think you can help me learn how to mount a TV to a wall?

How do I choose the spot on the wall to attach the mount to?

preferred_completion: There are several ways.  One is to use a stud-finder. The third way is to measure the distance from a known stud on one side of the wall, to the nearest stud on the other side.

input.content: What time is sunrise at this time of year?

As the sky darkens from this time through midnight, the lengthening of the twilight period is offset by a shortened sunrise and sunset period.  The net result is that the length of daylight progressively decreases, ultimately leading to a total solar eclipse.  Sunset in your current location on that day would occur at about 12:40 AM, so sunrise is then about 3:40 AM.  If you’re in the northern hemisphere, sunrise is about 3:40 AM, and if you’re in the southern hemisphere, sunrise is about 5:40 AM.  Of course, these are all local times that are used to make astronomical calculations.  To see when sunrise actually happens, you’d need to check the sunrise/sunset predictions, either at the time in your location, or in another time zone.
Does sunrise get later in the winter?

Yes, so in general you can think of sunrise as “getting later” as the months progress through the calendar year.  The most far northern/southern locations will see the earliest sunrise on the summer solstice, while the southernmost locations will see the latest sunrise on the winter solstice.

Ingredients:

1/2 cup sweetened condensed milk

1/2 cup melted butter or margarine

1 tsp vanilla extract

1/2 cup flour

1/4 tsp salt

1 cup of chocolate chips

Method:

- Melt the butter or margarine, and add the vanilla extract.

- In a medium mixing bowl, combine the condensed milk, melted butter, and vanilla extract.  Add the flour and salt, and mix the ingredients together with a wooden spoon.  Stir in the chocolate chips.

input.content: I'm trying to find out what the different phases of the moon are. Can you help?
Sure.  There are several lunar phases, where a full moon in the night sky looks somewhat different from a full moon in the daytime.  You can learn about the phases of the moon here.
Got it, but can you please identify the four lunar phases of the moon?

preferred_completion:
Yes. The phases of the moon refer to how much the moon is illuminated by the sun:

- New Moon - The moon is completely in shadow, and therefore completely dark in the night sky.  You cannot see any portion of the moon because it is completely dark.

- Waxing Crescent - The moon has started to move out of shadow and you can see a small portion of it in the night sky.  This is the first visible phase of the moon.

- Waxing Gibbous - You can see the entire upper half of the moon in the sky.  This is halfway between a crescent and a full moon.

- Full Moon - The moon is completely illuminated by the sun.  This is the brightest phase of the moon.

- Waning Gibbous - You can see the entire lower half of the moon in the sky.  This is halfway between the full moon and a crescent.

- Waning Crescent - You can see less and less of the moon as it disappears back into shadow.  This is the final visible phase of the moon.
other_completion: Sure, the four lunar phases are New Moon, Waxing Crescent, First Quarter, and Waning Crescent, but they’re not the same every time, because the moon’s shape and size change as it goes through the different stages of its phases.  For example, sometimes the crescent is mostly-new moon, sometimes mostly-waxing crescent, sometimes mostly-first quarter, and sometimes mostly-waning crescent.

input.content: What was Yugoslavia and what happened to it?

The breakup of Yugoslavia was a process that occurred over the course of two years, starting in 1991.  Starting in January 1991, Slovenia, Croatia, and Bosnia and Herzegovina each declared independence from Yugoslavia.  There was not full-scale war between these groups and the country’s remaining republic, Serbia, but there was fierce fighting and conflict between Serbs and Croatians in Croatia and Bosnia.  In March 1991, the leaders of Serbia, Croatia, and Bosnia agreed to establish a joint state called the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia.  After Serbia’s president Slobodan Milosevic threatened to create a Greater Serbia if Bosnia and Herzegovina would not agree to a centralized state, Croatia and Bosnia declared their independence in 1991.  A further agreement was made in 1992 that all the former republics would join a loose association of states known as the “Federal Republic of Yugoslavia”, and this was accepted in the U.N. as the successor state to Yugoslavia.  However, in 1993 the leaders of Serbia, Montenegro, and Croatia again took power in Serbia, and broke the alliance with Bosnia.  A war began between Serbia and Bosnia, which killed thousands and led to the refugee crisis that lasted into the 21
Did the breakup happen after President Josip Broz Tito died?

No, the breakup occurred when the people who became the presidents of the new states were just starting out as public figures.  Slovenia, Croatia, and Bosnia all held free elections as soon as possible, in 1992, to elect new leaders.  President Josip Broz Tito did not become head of Yugoslavia until the country became independent from the Soviet Union in 1945.  It wasn’t until 1980 that he declared the country to be a “socialist” state, but other groups in the country disliked that, and by the early 1990s many were calling for Yugoslavia to become a “federal republic” or to dissolve altogether.
Please summarize.  Yugoslavia became how many countries now?  What are the names of the countries?

Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, Kosovo, Macedonia, Montenegro, Serbia, and Slovenia.  The larger republics that remained are Serbia, Croatia, Bosnia, and Montenegro, with Slovenia and Macedonia as the two smaller republics.
Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, Kosovo, Macedonia, Montenegro, Serbia, and Slovenia. Are they communist countries?  Which one has the most Muslims and which one has the most Christians?

I’m not sure of your definition of “communist”, so let me explain some facts about each.  Croatia is the country that has a majority of ethnic Serbs.  Bosnia and Herzegovina is the country that has the most Muslims.  Slovenia, Serbia, and Montenegro are all more than 50% ethnic Serbs.  As for which has the most Christians, there are more Catholics in Bosnia and Herzegovina, but a bigger number of Orthodox Christians in Montenegro.  The former Soviet Union (including parts of Russia) is predominantly Orthodox.
Are Bosnia and Herzegovina two different countries?

preferred_completion: No, that is a common mistake.  Bosnia and Herzegovina is a single country.
other_completion: They are, but they are generally included in the same region, the Balkans.

input.content: How can I clarify butter?

preferred_completion: If you are making homemade butter, you should warm your milk and cream on the stove until just the first bubbles form around the edges, and stir continuously to keep the temperature around 100 degrees. Then remove the pan from the heat.  Next add a bit of lemon juice or vinegar.  Carefully skim off the foam.  Add the clarifying agent, usually vinegar or lemon juice, and stir again.  Pour the liquid butter into a bowl and set it aside, ideally in a cool place.  After a while, the watery liquid will separate from the butter.  Skim the top layer off to get your clarifying butter, which can be poured into a clean jar.  You can now make the final butter that will be used for cooking or baking by slowly adding the watery liquid to the jar of clarified butter.  This will help incorporate the fat from the liquid into the clarified butter.

input.content: How do home vacuums work?

Some home vacuums have a little bristling brush that brushes across the carpet to pick up dirt, dust, and other particles.  The vacuum can be connected to a hose that goes outside, so that the dust and dirt can be sucked outside.  Inside, the dust and dirt are carried into a removable bag.  Usually, it’s easy to get these bags replaced, so that vacuuming can be done on a regular schedule, since the bags will fill up over time.  If you have a hardwood floor in your house, you’ll have to vacuum carefully to avoid scratching the floor.
What are all the parts inside a vacuum?

Vacuums usually have a main fan that pulls air out of the vacuum, then there’s the motor that turns the fan.  Then there’s the dust collection bag, which collects the dust and dirt, and is sometimes known as the “bag”.  Other parts include bristles or a brush that moves the dust into the collection bag, the collection bag holder, a hose that brings air in and out of the vacuum, and the electrical wires that provide power to the vacuum.
Is there a belt in a vacuum? I remember a burning rubber smell coming from a vacuum once.

You may be thinking of a floor vacuum, which can be used for cleaning carpets.  These tend to have a rubber belt that takes in the carpet fibers.  The rubber belt is heated to make it more efficient at picking up dirt.  This is often called a “heat and dirt” belt.  The heat and dirt belt is then pulled to the vacuum with the rest of the dirt from the floor.  Vacuums can have an electric motor or a gasoline engine, and the motor or engine powers the belt as well.  Floor vacuums have a hose that you can hook to another part of the vacuum to suck up the dirt.  It’s good to make sure that the hose isn’t kinked, so that the vacuum will work right.
Is a broken vacuum easy to fix myself or will I have to take it to a company to fix it?

A vacuum cleaner is a relatively simple machine, but it’s also easy to accidentally break it.  The bristles can become damaged or broken, or the main brush that collects dirt and dust can break or fall apart.  Most vacuums don’t have moving parts, but they can still break down.  Often if a vacuum breaks it’s because it wasn’t properly taken care of.  However, the parts are simple enough that sometimes you can repair them yourself.  But if you don’t have the technical skills, or your vacuum is complicated, it’s often a good idea to take the vacuum to a repair shop or professional company.
And how does a vacuum keep the dust and dirt from just spewing out into the air?

preferred_completion: The bag acts as a filter, which catches the dirt and dirt.  Usually, the bag can be replaced with a new one, so it’s easier to maintain the vacuum.  You can also get a “bagless” vacuum, in which the air passes through a “cyclone” chamber and goes through a series of screens to capture the dirt.
other_completion: That’s a good question.  Vacuums have a lot of different parts, but the most important one is the main “bag” or “basket”, which is used to collect the dust.  Inside the bag, the dust is trapped, and the air passes through the bag so that it can be exhausted from the vacuum.

input.content: Can you tell me what happened in the Prohibition?

The Prohibition was a time when alcohol and beer were prohibited for sale in the United States. The Prohibition Act, also called the Volstead Act after the congressman who authored the law, outlawed the sale of alcohol except for “medicinal, mechanical, or manufacturing” uses.
when did this happen? and why?
The Prohibition was passed in 1919, and it was enforced until it was repealed by the 21st Amendment to the United States Constitution, in 1933.
That is correct. Why was the Prohibition brought in?

preferred_completion: During the period of time in which Prohibition was enacted, public opinion towards the sale and consumption of alcohol was very negative. After a number of scandals in the public eye, many people were appalled by the state of alcohol abuse in the United States and favored the law in an attempt to curtail the negative impacts. The most influential of these scandals was the murder of a prominent industrialist named William Randolph Hearst by a would-be assassin. The assassin was a vagrant, who was convicted of the crime under extremely prejudicial conditions. The details of the case showed that the killer had a very serious and long-standing alcohol addiction. Public opinion at the time of the trial favored the idea that the killer was a killer-not a drunk, but an individual who did not do what he did through willpower and determination, but instead, due to the weakness and inability to control his alcohol consumption. In the aftermath of the trial, public opinion was very negatively polarized towards alcohol, and people were eager to pursue measures that would restrict or completely prohibit the sale of alcohol. As a result, Prohibition was brought in.
other_completion: At the time, many people in the US were disturbed by the rising levels of crime and alcoholism. Many people also believed that alcohol was a primary cause of these problems, and they saw Prohibition as an opportunity to decrease them. The argument that alcohol led to a loss of respect for personal rights, and that it led to other problems, was especially important during the time of prohibition.

input.content: Is the United Kingdom a monarchy?
No, the United Kingdom is a democracy, with a hereditary monarchy.
What does the Queen do then since the United Kingdom is a democracy?

The Queen is the ceremonial head of state of the United Kingdom. This means that she often visits and meets the Prime Minister, but has no power over politics. She also hosts various events. For example, she welcomes foreign leaders to Britain and holds annual meetings with the UK Prime Minister. The Queen has no direct power over policy making, but is the head of the state and represents Britain abroad and throughout the Commonwealth.

preferred_completion: The longest serving monarch was Queen Victoria. She reigned for 63 years from 1837 until her death in 1901.
other_completion: George III was the longest serving monarch of the United Kingdom. He ruled from 1760 to 1820. His son, George IV, was the next longest serving monarch.
